title: Problem Overview
content: **Erdős Problem #377** asks if the sum of 1/p over primes p ≤ n that DON'T divide C(2n, n) is uniformly bounded. EGRS75 proved statistical results but the main conjecture is OPEN.
mathContext: The central binomial coefficient C(2n,n) = (2n)!/(n!)² is highly composite. Most primes p ≤ n divide it, so the question is whether the 'exceptional' primes have bounded reciprocal sum.

title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import **Central** for central binomials, **ArithmeticFunction** for primality, **Log.Basic** for logarithms, **InfiniteSum.Real** for series, and **Cofinite** for 'almost all' statements.

title: The Function f(n)
content: **sumInvPrimesNotDivCentralBinom n** computes ∑_{p ≤ n, p ∤ C(2n,n)} 1/p — the sum of reciprocals of primes that 'miss' the central binomial.
mathContext: By Kummer's theorem, p | C(2n,n) iff there's a carry when adding n + n in base p. Primes NOT dividing are those where all base-p digits of n are < p/2.

title: The Boundedness Conjecture
content: **BoundedConjectureHolds**: ∃ C > 0, ∀ n, f(n) ≤ C. This asks whether the 'exceptional' primes have uniformly bounded reciprocal sum.
mathContext: The conjecture remains OPEN. Intuitively, 'most' primes divide C(2n,n), so the complement should be small — but proving uniform boundedness is difficult.

title: Main Theorem Statement
content: **erdos_377**: States the main open question as an equivalence — BoundedConjectureHolds iff the explicit bound exists.
mathContext: This is definitionally true (rfl) since BoundedConjectureHolds is exactly that condition. The theorem serves as the formal problem statement.

title: The Constant γ₀
content: **gamma0** = ∑_{k=2}^∞ log(k)/2^k ≈ 0.7943. This constant appears throughout EGRS75's analysis of the average behavior of f(n).
mathContext: The series converges rapidly. This constant measures the 'typical' value of f(n) for almost all n.

title: EGRS First Moment
content: **egrs_first_moment**: (1/x)∑_{n≤x} f(n) → γ₀ as x → ∞. The Cesàro mean of f(n) converges to γ₀.
mathContext: This shows f(n) is 'typically' about γ₀ ≈ 0.794. But average convergence doesn't bound the maximum.

title: EGRS Second Moment
content: **egrs_second_moment**: (1/x)∑_{n≤x} f(n)² → γ₀² as x → ∞. The Cesàro mean of f(n)² equals the square of the first moment limit.
mathContext: Combined with the first moment, this implies Var(f) = E[f²] - E[f]² → γ₀² - γ₀² = 0. So f(n) concentrates around γ₀.

title: Almost Everywhere Result
content: **egrs_almost_everywhere**: For almost all n, f(n) = γ₀ + o(1). The function approaches γ₀ for 'most' integers.
mathContext: This follows from the variance → 0 argument. The cofinite filter captures 'all but finitely many' integers.

title: EGRS Upper Bound
content: **egrs_upper_bound**: f(n) ≤ c·log(log(n)) for some c < 1 and all large n. This improves the trivial Mertens bound.
mathContext: Mertens' theorem gives ∑_{p≤n} 1/p ~ log(log n), so f(n) ≤ log(log n) trivially. EGRS improved the constant to c < 1.

title: Complementary Sum
content: **sumInvPrimesDividingCentralBinom** — the sum over primes that DO divide C(2n,n). This is the 'complement' of f(n).
mathContext: The two functions partition ∑_{p≤n} 1/p. If f(n) is bounded, then the dividing primes contribute (1-o(1))log(log n).

title: Complementary Sums Lemma
content: **complementary_sums**: f(n) + g(n) = ∑_{p≤n} 1/p where g is the dividing-prime sum. The two functions partition all primes.
mathContext: This is straightforward from definitions: each prime p ≤ n either divides C(2n,n) or doesn't, contributing to exactly one sum.
